questions.text: A patient presents with fever and acute pain over thigh. There is  swelling in the mid thigh region. Lamellated appearance is seen on X-ray and immune-histochemical staining is positive for MIC-2. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis, in this case, is Ewing's sarcoma.

A diaphyseal tumour presenting with fever, pain and swelling suggests Ewing's sarcoma. Classically, Ewing's sarcoma appears radiographically as a destructive lesion in the diaphysis with the lamellar "onion skin" periosteal reaction. Immunohistochemical staining for MIC-2 is specific for Ewing’s sarcoma. It has its highest incidence in second decade of life.

questions.text: Blood pressure of a person on day 1 was 142/90 mm of Hg. After 2 days the blood pressure of the same person measured with the same apparatus under the same emotional and physical state of the person by different doctor reads 160/98. Which error is mainly responsible for this reading?
questions.solution:
Observer errors arise due to difference in hearing acuity and interpretation of korotkoff sounds.

The types of errors identified in the measurement of blood pressures:

  • Observer errors - due to difference in hearing acuity, interpretation of korotkoff sounds.
  • Instrumental errors - due to a leaking valve or cuffs that do not encircle the arm completely.
  • Subject errors - due to the anxiety, fear, etc.

questions.text: A 30 year old woman came to OPD with a twin pregnancy at 10 weeks of gestation. She has a 3 year old female child who was born at term and had 2 first trimester abortions previously. Which of the following is the correct representation of her obstetric score/formula. G=gravid, P= para:
questions.solution:
The obstetric score is G4P1A2L1.

Gravida: Total number of pregnancies including the present one.
Para: Total number of pregnancies crossing the period of viability, which is 28 weeks in India.

As such, a woman who delivers twins in the first pregnancy is still a gravida 1 and para 1. A pregnant woman with a previous history of 2 abortions and 1 term delivery can be expressed as 4th Gravida but primipara.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man working in the ship repair industry presents with a gradually progressive cough and difficulty breathing. The flow-volume curve after spirometry in the patient is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

Pink line - Patient's response
Green dashed lines - Normal response
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in a 48-year-old patient working in a ship repair industry with a restrictive pattern on the flow-volume curve is asbestosis. Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis reveals a restrictive pattern with a decrease in both lung volumes and diffusing capacity.

The flow-volume curve of the above (patient 1) shows decreased total lung capacity, vital capacity, and residual volume. Hence, the loop shrinks or narrows and shifts towards the right. This is seen in restrictive lung disease. Airflow is greater than normal at comparable lung volumes because the increased elastic recoil of the lungs holds the airways open.

Asthma, COPD, emphysema, and endobronchial neoplasm present with obstructive flow patterns. Although all airflow is diminished, expiratory prolongation predominates, and mean expiratory flow < mean inspiratory flow. The increased total lung capacity, vital capacity, and residual volume will shift the flow volume loop to left.

Vocal cord paralysis causes a variable extrathoracic upper airway obstruction in which only the inspiratory curve would be flattened.

 

Asbestosis is a diffuse interstitial fibrosing disease of the lung directly related to the intensity and duration of exposure. 

Asbestos fibers induce oxidative injury due to the generation of reactive oxygen species by the transition metals on the surface of the fibers as well as from cells engaged in phagocytosis. These mechanisms result in lung fibrosis.

Irregular or linear opacities initially in the lower lung fields are the hallmark of asbestosis in chest radiographs. A gound glass appearance in the lung fields may be seen.

The chest X-ray below shows bilateral calcified pleural plaques consistent with asbestos-related pleural disease:

 

No specific therapy is available for asbestosis. They are managed with supportive therapy. The most common cancer associated with asbestos exposure is lung cancer. Pleural and peritoneal mesothelioma are also associated with asbestos exposure. 

Other options:

Options A and B: Emphysema and asthma are obstructive lung disorders. In these conditions, the flow-volume loop would be a scooped-out curve.

Option D: Vocal cord paralysis causes variable extrathoracic upper airway obstruction. The flow-volume loop would have a flat inspiratory curve.

Related Pearl: PFT for obstructive vs restrictive diseases

PFT

Obstructive disease

Restrictive disease

FVC

Decreased

Decreased (<80% predicted)

FEV1

Decreased (<80% predicted)

 Decreased

FEV1% (FEV1/FVC)

Decreased (<0.7)

Normal/ increased (>0.7)

FEF 25-75

<50% predicted

Normal/ decreased

TLC

Normal/ increased

Decreased

RV

Increased

Decreased

DLCO
  • Normal or increased in asthma
  • Decreased in emphysema
  • Decreased in intrinsic restrictive disease
  • Normal in neuromuscular or musculoskeletal restrictive disease

FVC: Forced Vital Capacity

FEV1: Forced expiratory volume in 1 second

FEF 25-75: Forced expiratory flow at 25-75% vital capacity

TLC: Total lung capacity

RV: Residual volume

DLCO: Diffusion capacity of lung for Carbon monoxide.

Related Pearl: Flow-volume graph/Loop

questions.text: A 38-year-old man was brought to the emergency department after suffering a stab injury to the lower chest. On presentation, he had bradycardia and hypotension. The blood pressure has not improved despite the ​administration of  IV fluids. Chest radiography showed clear lung fields. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The next step in the management of this patient is to perform an eFast examination.

Persistent hypotension despite initial fluid resuscitation indicates an ongoing haemorrhage. It is mostly fatal if not controlled, and the source of hemorrhage must be identified by eFast, chest and pelvic radiographs.

questions.text: A patient with ptosis presented with retraction of the ptotic eyelid on chewing.  What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A patient with ptosis presented with retraction of the ptotic eyelid on chewing. The diagnosis is Marcus–Gunn jaw-winking phenomenon.

  • About 5% of all cases of congenital ptosis are associated with the Marcus–Gunn jaw-winking phenomenon.
  • The vast majority are unilateral.
  • Etiology: a branch of the mandibular division of the fifth cranial nerve is misdirected to the levator muscle.
  • Signs
    • Retraction of the ptotic lid in conjunction with stimulation of the ipsilateral pterygoid muscles by chewing, sucking, opening the mouth, or contralateral jaw movement.
    • Less common stimuli to winking include jaw protrusion, smiling, swallowing, and clenching of teeth.
    • Jaw-winking does not improve with age although patients may learn to mask it.

Image: The woman cannot control her eyelids while drinking

questions.text: An 11-year-old girl was brought by her parents with complaints of weight loss, increased appetite and a decline in scholastic performance. Following investigations, a diagnosis of Grave’s disease is made. Which of the following is the drug of choice for initial therapy?
questions.solution:
Methimazole is the initial drug of choice for treating Grave's disease (hyperthyroidism) in children.

Both methimazole and propylthiouracil are anti-thyroid drugs, but the use of propylthiouracil in children has been associated with fatal hepatotoxicity.

In Pregnancy,

  • Methimazole crosses the placenta to a greater degree than propylthiouracil and has been associated with fetal aplasia cutis.
  • Propylthiouracil should be used in the first trimester, and then, maternal therapy should be converted to methimazole (or carbimazole).

 Other options:

  • Radioactive iodine is not preferred as the first-line treatment in hyperthyroidism for children.
  • Levothyroxine is used to treat hypothyroidism.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male was diagnosed with a submandibular gland tumour and underwent  removal of the tumour following which lingual nerve was found to be damaged. Which of the following statements are not correct?

choices.text: Sensation of floor of mouth lost
Sensation of anterior two-third of tongue lost
Sensation of posterior one-third of tongue lost

questions.solution:
Sensation of posterior 1/3rd of tongue is carried by the Glossopharngeal nerve and hence this statement is incorrect.

In the anterior two-thirds of the tongue,

  • General sensation is carried by the lingual nerve.
  • Taste sensation is carried by chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve.

In the posterior one-third of the tongue,

  • Both general and taste sensations are carried by the glossopharyngeal nerve.

Valleculae (portion between anterior 2/3rd and posterior 1/3rd of the tongue) is supplied by the internal laryngeal branch of the vagus nerve.

Related Pearl: Sensory Innervation of Tongue

Area

General sensory

Special sensory

Anterior 2/3rds

Lingual nerve (CN V)

Chorda tympani (CN VII)

Posterior 1/3rd

Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)

Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)

Posterior most tongue (vallecullae, epiglottis)

Internal laryngeal nerve (CN X)

Internal laryngeal nerve (CN X)

questions.text: A patient presents with pruritic hypopigmented macules and confluent patches over the chest as seen in the image. On KOH mount, spaghetti and meatballs appearance is noted. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
The characteristic appearance of ‘spaghetti and meatballs’ or ‘bananas and grapes' on KOH mount and microscopy (shown below) is suggestive of tinea versicolor or pityriasis versicolor. 

Pityriasis Versicolor is characterized by asymptomatic hypopigmented or hyperpigmented macules and patches and produces fine scales (branny/furfuraceous).

Tinea versicolor is usually caused by the lipophilic fungi Malassezia globosa and possibly Malassezia sympodialis and Malassezia furfur.

Mechanism of hypopigmentation in P. Versicolor: Azelaic acid produced by Malassezia species.

Pale yellow fluorescence in Wood’s lamp examination is another characteristic finding of tinea versicolor. Besnier's sign (coup d'ongle sign, scratch sign, stroke of the nail): When the fine scales are not visible, an important diagnostic clue may be the loosening of barely perceptible scale with a fingernail, which is called as the scratch sign.

Patients are treated with Topical azoles.

Option A: Tinea cruris, also known as jock itch, is a dermatophyte infection affecting the inguinal folds, which may extend to the vulva and perianal area. 

Option B:  Tinea capitis, also known as scalp ringworm, is a fungal infection affecting the scalp. 

Option C: Tinea corporis, is a fungal infection, which can occur anywhere in the body, with the classical ring shaped/annular rash. 

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's Lamp Examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp. Black light is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

Table: Various diseases and their color on Wood’s lamp examination

Disease

Colour on Wood’s Light

Tinea capitis

 

Microsporum species: blue-green (M. canis, M. audouinii, M. ferrugineum, M. distortum); 

Trichophyton schoenleinii: dull blue.

Most Trichophyton species, with the exception of T. schoenleinii, are non-fluorescent

 

Erythrasma

Coral pink

Pityriasis versicolor

Faint yellow

Pseudomonas

Green

Scabies

Fluorescein solution fills the burrows and fluoresces on Wood’s light.

Porphyria

Urine, feces, blister fluid fluoresce red or pink

Vitiligo

Ivory or milky white

questions.text: A  pregnant woman in her 7th week comes to your clinic complaining of irritation and profuse greenish frothy discharge from her vagina. Which of the following can be used to treat her condition?
questions.solution:
Vinegar douching can be done safely in pregnancy, to treat Trichomoniasis.

T. vaginalis infection in pregnant women is associated with adverse pregnancy outcomes like premature rupture of membranes, preterm delivery, and low birthweight infant.

 The treatment options include:

  • An oral dose of metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days or single oral dose of metronidazole 2 g  
  • Vinegar douche to lower the vaginal PH
  • Trichofuran suppositories
  • Betadine gel

The male partner should be treated with a single dose of oral metronidazole in case of recurrent infection.

questions.text: A vibrating tuning fork is placed on the mastoid while the examiner alternately closes and opens the ear canal by pressing on the tragus inwards. A normal person or one with sensorineural hearing loss hears louder when ear canal is occluded and softer when the canal is open. This test is known as:
questions.solution:
The given test is Bing test.

It is a test of bone conduction and examines the effect of occlusion of ear canal on the hearing.  A vibrating tuning fork is placed on the mastoid while the examiner alternately closes and opens the ear canal by pressing on the tragus inwards. A normal person or one with sensorineural hearing loss hears louder when the ear canal is occluded and softer when the canal is open (Bing positive). A patient with conductive hearing loss will appreciate no change (Bing negative).

questions.text: Post-coital test was performed in a couple who presented with inability to conceive in spite of staying together for 4 years and having unprotected intercourse. This test can detect all of the following, except?
questions.solution:
The post-coital test is not useful to detect fallopian tube block.

Post-coital test (Sims’ or Huhner’s test):

  • The couple is advised intercourse close to the ovulation time, preferably in the early hours of the morning. The woman presents herself at the clinic within 2 h after the intercourse. The mucus is aspirated from the cervical canal and spread over a glass slide.
  • Another smear made from the posterior fornix serves as a control. Normally 10–50 motile sperms are seen per high-power field in cervical mucus.
  • The cervical mucus is simultaneously examined for its quantity, viscosity, and fern test.

The advantage of this test is that the cervical mucus can be simultaneously studied for oestrogenic effect and ovulation, its capability to allow sperm penetration, and presence of any anti-sperm antibodies. The test is useless in the presence of cervical infection, which should be treated before performing the post-coital test.

Immunological factor is encountered in 5% cases.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman who is in her 12th week of gestation was referred to you by an obstetrician for sonographic evaluation. You notice the following sign on USG. What is the sign and the significance of the sign that is demonstrated in this image?
questions.solution:
The image shows the lambda sign or twin peak sign seen in dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy.

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick septum between the two gestational sacs.

A triangular projection is seen at the base of the membrane. This is known as lambda or twin peak sign. The presence of lambda or twin peak sign indicates a dichorionic placenta.

Note: "T sign" is the sonographic image seen in a monochorionic twin pregnancy. It refers to the lack of chorion extending between the layers of the intertwin membrane.

Related Pearl: Important radiological signs in OBG

Sign
Significance
Bagel sign
Gestational sac in the adnexa with a hyperechoic ring.
USG sign in tubal ectopic.
Ball Sign
X-ray shows a crumpled up spine of the fetus.
Radiological sign of intrauterine fetal death.
Banana Sign
Abnormal anterior curvature of the cerebellum due to the associated Arnold-Chiari malformation.
USG sign in open spina bifida.
Double decidual sac Sign
Two concentric echogenic rings separated by a hyperechoic space.
Normal USG appearance of an intrauterine gestational sac.
Lambda Sign
The chorionic tissue in between the two layers of the membrane between the twins.
USG sign seen in di-chorionic pregnancies.
‘T’ Sign
USG sign seen in monochorionic twins. As the intertwin membrane does not have any chorionic tissue it gives rise to ‘T’ sign in ultrasound.
Bunch of grapes sign
USG appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.
Butterfly sign
Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.
Cloverleaf skull
Seen in craniosynostosis
Empty amnion sign
Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A patient operated for direct inguinal hernia developed sensory loss at the root of penis and adjacent part of scrotum. The nerve most likely to have been injured is ________.
questions.solution:
Loss of sensation in the root of the penis and adjacent part of the scrotum is suggestive of an injury to the ilioinguinal nerve. It is most commonly injured within the inguinal canal in open hernia repair due to traction or thermal injury.

Injury to genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve results in loss of sensation in the skin of scrotum of males, and loss of sensation of the mons pubis and labia majora in females. 

The iliohypogastric nerve carries the sensory supply from the suprapubic area. Injury to this nerve within the inguinal canal rarely causes sensory disturbances, as the suprapubic area has a rich nerve supply from other sources too. If the nerve is severed above the anterior superior iliac spine, it can lead to the weakened posterior wall of the inguinal canal resulting in direct inguinal hernia.

questions.text:
The lung function of a patient is tested using a spirometer, and the following recording is noted. The technician looks at the graph and enters the following values in the report.
Volumes Values
1. Tidal volume  500 mL
2. Inspiratory reserve volume 2L
3. Expiratory reserve volume 1L
4. Inspiratory capacity 4.5L
5. Expiratory capacity 1.5L
6. Vital capacity 3.5L

Which among the following capacities has been incorrectly calculated by the technician?
questions.solution:
The technician has recorded inspiratory reserve volume, inspiratory capacity, and vital capacity wrongly.

In the above graph, 

Tidal volume (TV) is the amount of air that moves into the lungs with each inspiration or the amount of air that moves out with each expiration during quiet breathing. In this patient it is 0.5L. The normal values are 500-750 mL.

Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV) is the air inspired with a maximal inspiratory effort in excess of the tidal volume. In this patient, it is 6-3L = 3L. The normal values are around 2L.

Expiratory reserve volume (ERV) is the volume expelled by an active expiratory effort after passive expiration. In this patient it is 2.5-1.5 = 1L. The normal value is around 1L.

Inspiratory capacity (IC) is the maximum amount of air inspired from the end-expiratory level. It can be calculated as TV+IRV which is 0.5L + 3L= 3.5L. The normal value is around 2.5L.

Expiratory capacity (EC) is the maximum amount of air expired after a normal inspiration. It is calculated as TV+ERV, which is 0.5L + 1L = 1.5 L. Normal value is around 1.5L

Vital capacity (VC) refers to the maximum amount of air expired after full inspiration. It is calculated as TV+IRV+ERV. In this patient it is 0.5+ 3+1 =4.5L. The normal value is around 3.5L.

Other important lung values:

The forced vital capacity (FVC), is the largest amount of air that can be expired after a maximal inspiratory effort.

Forced expiratory volume in the first second, FEV1, is the fraction of the vital capacity expired during the first second. 

Respiratory minute volume (RVV) is a measurement of the amount of air that enters the lungs per minute. It is calculated as respiratory rate X tidal volume.

Maximal voluntary respiration (MVV), is the largest volume of gas that can be moved into and out of the lungs in 1 min by voluntary effort.

Total lung capacity is the total volume of the lung. It can be calculated by adding tidal volume, inspiratory reserve volume, expiratory reserve volume, and residual volume. Normal total lung capacity is around 5L.

Related Pearl: Lung volumes and capacities

Measurement

Description

Normal Value

Tidal volume (TV)

The amount of air that moves into the lungs with each inspiration (or the amount that moves out with each expiration) during quiet breathing

500–750 mL.

Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV)

The air inspired with a maximal inspiratory effort in excess of the TV

∼3 L

Expiratory reserve volume (ERV)

The volume expelled by an active expiratory effort after passive expiration

∼1.1 L

Residual volume (RV)

The air left in the lungs after a maximal expiratory effort

∼1.2 L

Total lung capacity (TLC)

IRV+TV+ERV+RV

∼5.8 L

Vital capacity (VC)

IRV+TV+ERV

∼4.5 L

Inspiratory capacity (IC)

TV+IRV

∼3.5 L

Expiratory capacity (EC)

TV+ERV

∼1.5 L

Functional residual capacity (FRC)

ERV+RV

∼2.3 L

questions.text: A 35-year-old model with a history of binge eating followed by self-induced vomiting; BMI is 23. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of binge eating followed by self-induced vomiting with normal weight is suggestive of bulimia nervosa.

Bulimia can be differentiated from anorexia nervosa by the below features:

  • The body weight is within the normal range.
  • Bulimia is seen in older age groups (late adolescents or adults).
  • Any peculiar eating habit (like dividing food into small portions) is not seen.
  • Amenorrhoea is not common.
  • Psychiatric symptoms such as depression are more common.

Treatment of bulimia nervosa:

  • Without comorbid mood disorders: Fluoxetine, topiramate, CBT
  • With comorbid mood disorders: Carbamazepine

 

Related Pearl: Eating Disorders

 

Anorexia nervosa

Bulimia nervosa

Binge-eating disorder

Avoidance of food

(calorie deficit)

+

-

-

Binge eating

+/-

+

(purge/vomit)

 +/-

+

-

BMI

LOW*

NORMAL

 *In atypical anorexia nervosa, all the features of anorexia nervosa will be present, but the patient will have normal BMI.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant with abdominal distension, fever, and jaundice was brought to the pediatric outpatient department. Urine examination revealed a boiled cabbage odor. What is the likely disorder?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario and the boiled cabbage odor on urine examination is hepatorenal tyrosinemia. 

There are three types of tyrosinemias:

  • Type 1 tyrosinemia also known as hepatorenal tyrosinemia is an autosomal recessive condition. The defective enzyme is fumaryl acetoacetate hydrolase. Clinical features are liver failure, hypoglycemia, boiled cabbage odor in the urine, and mental retardation. 
  • Type 2 is known as oculocutaneous tyrosinemia or Richner-Hanhart syndrome. The defective enzyme is tyrosine transaminase. Clinical features are palmoplantar keratosis, painful corneal erosions, photophobia, and mental retardation.
  • Type 3 is known as neonatal tyrosinemia. It is due to the deficiency of 4-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate hydroxylase. Clinical features include normal liver function, developmental delay, seizures, and intermittent ataxia.

Hawkinsinuria is an autosomal dominant condition. It is due to the dysfunction of 4-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate oxidase. Clinical features are failure to thrive and metabolic acidosis in infancy.

Note: Boiled cabbage odor can also be found in cases of hypermethioninemia.

Related Pearl: Amino acid Enzymatic Disorders and the Associated Enzymes

Enzyme defect

Maple syrup urine disease

Alkaptonuria

Homogentisate oxidase

Tyrosinase

Homocystinuria type I

Homocystinuria type II

Cystathioninuria

Tyrosine transaminase or Tyrosine aminotransferase

Hypervalinemia

questions.text:
A 50-year-old smoker and hypertensive male, complaints of exertional angina. He says it occurs almost daily now, from a very long time. ECG shows ST depression. On cardiac evaluation, there is no increase in the levels of cardiac biomarkers. What could be the most probable diagnosis of the patient?

Non-ST elevation myocardial infarction- NSTEMI

ST-elevation myocardial infarction- STEMI
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is unstable angina.

Unstable angina is chest discomfort or pain due to insufficient blood flow and oxygen to the heart. It occurs due to the development of the thrombus on a pre-existing disrupted atherosclerotic plaque and is non-occlusive. The patients develop chest pain radiating to the jaws or arms and shortness of breath. 

An electrocardiogram may show hyperacute T-wave, T-wave flattening, inverted T-waves, and ST depression in unstable angina. Unstable angina is diagnosed in patients with symptoms suggestive of acute coronary syndrome with no elevation of cardiac biomarkers. If cardiac biomarkers are elevated in these patients, then the diagnosis of myocardial infarction is considered.

Acute coronary syndromes (ACS) include:

  • Unstable angina(UA).
  • Non-ST elevation myocardial infarction(NSTEMI).
  • ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI).

Other options:

Option A: NSTEMI is one of the components of ACS in which there are ST-segment depression and deep T-wave inversions. The cardiac biomarkers are elevated in NSTEMI unlike in unstable angina.

Option B: STEMI is one of the components of ACS in which there is ST-segment elevation with T-wave changes. The cardiac biomarkers are elevated in STEMI.

Option C: Left heart failure results due to dysfunction of the left ventricle, leading to insufficient delivery of blood to vital organs. The electrocardiogram shows non-specific ischemic changes, left ventricle hypertrophy or arrhythmias. The cardiac biomarker like brain natriuretic peptide may be elevated.

questions.text: An elderly woman with hypothyroidism was found dead, and it appeared as if she had hid herself in her wardrobe. Which of the following most likely explains her scenario?
questions.solution:
Among the options, the most likely explanation is terminal burrowing behaviour or hide and die syndrome. 

An elderly lady with hypothyroidism is the ideal candidate to develop hypothermia. About 20% of hypothermia cases are associated with terminal burrowing behaviour. In some cases the bodies were found in strange situations, i.e. lying under a bed, behind a wardrobe, or in a shelf, etc. indicating that the final positions were a kind of self-protective burrowing-like behaviour.

  • This terminal burrowing behaviour only occurs in 20% of cases of death due to hypothermia.
  • The pathophysiology of this behaviour is not yet understood, but the current hypothesis is that it is a primitive response pattern of the brainstem.

questions.text: A three and a half year old child comes to the PHC completely unimmunised. Which of the following vaccines can be given to the child now?

choices.text: BCG, DPT-1, OPV-1, Measles, Vit A

questions.solution:
DPT-1, OPV-1, Measles, Vit A will be given to this child of 3.5 years of age in his first immunisation visit.

BCG can only be given up to 1 year of age, according to the National Immunisation Schedule. 

Please note that BCG can be given up to 5 years of age, as part of the catch up immunisation schedule which is by the Indian Academy of Paediatrics and that is not followed in government setups.

OPV can be given till 5 years of age.

Measles can be given till 5 years of age.

DPT can be given until 7 years of age (with booster doses).

Related Pearl: National Immunization Schedule (India)

questions.text: A screening test was carried out among 114 people of which 15 had the disease. 22  people tested positive for the disease among which 14 had the disease. What is the sensitivity of the test?
questions.solution:
In this scenario:

  • The total number of subjects is 114
  • Of the 114 subjects, 15 had the disease( Total disease) 
  • 22 tested positive meaning total subjects with test positive
  • Only 14 of the 22 had disease meaning true positives. This leaves 8 subjects as false positives. 
  • Of the 15 who had disease, 14 tested positive implying only 1 subject was false negative. 

 

Disease +

Disease -

Total

Test +

14 (TP)

8 (FP)

22

Test -

1 (FN)

91 (TN)

92

Total

15

99

114

Sensitivity is given as TP/(TP + FN) x 100 = 14/(14+1)= 14/15

Thus, sensitivity is 93.3%.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ Accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Speciifity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy with progressive muscle weakness and walking difficulties is presented with the following finding. Dystrophin gene mutation was found to be present. The given clinical condition is associated with what chromosome?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and the image showing pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles is highly suggestive of Duchenne muscular dystrophy and it is associated with chromosome X.

Muscle Dystrophy:

Duchenne and Becker muscular dystrophy are caused by loss-of-function mutations in the dystrophin gene on the X chromosome. Dystrophin is one of the largest human genes. Dystrophin is thought to provide mechanical stability to the myofiber and its cell membrane during muscle contraction. Defects in the complex may lead to small membrane tears that permit the influx of calcium, triggering events that result in myofiber degeneration.

Duchenne muscular dystrophy is typically associated with deletions or frame-shift mutations that result in the total absence of dystrophin. In contrast, the mutations in Becker muscular dystrophy typically permit the synthesis of a truncated version of dystrophin, which presumably retains some function. Immunohistochemical studies for dystrophin show the absence of the normal sarcolemmal staining pattern in Duchenne muscular dystrophy and reduced staining in Becker muscular dystrophy.

Definitive therapy requires the restoration of dystrophin levels in skeletal and cardiac muscle fibers.

  • One approach involves the expression of antisense RNAs that alter RNA splicing so as to cause the “skipping” of exons containing deleterious mutations, thus permitting the expression of a truncated, but partially functional, dystrophin protein.
  • A second strategy is exploring the use of drugs that promote ribosomal “read-through” of stop codons, another ploy that may enable the expression of some dystrophin protein.
  • Both of these approaches are mutation-specific and thus need to be tailored to individual patients.
  • Gene therapy (introduction of a normal dystrophin gene) is under investigation.

questions.text: An elderly patient with ventricular tachycardia has been started on amiodarone. Which of the following is the most important adverse event associated with this drug's use?
questions.solution:
The most important adverse event associated with the use of amiodarone is pulmonary fibrosis. 

Amiodarone is a class three anti-arrhythmic that is primarily used in the treatment of supraventricular arrhythmias, ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation.

Pulmonary fibrosis is usually seen in patients who take prolonged courses of amiodarone and in high doses.

Pulmonary fibrosis can be potentially life-threatening and requires immediate discontinuation of the amiodarone and initiation of high-dose corticosteroids.

Other adverse events associated with amiodarone use are nausea, photosensitivity, corneal microdeposits and thyroid dysfunction.

Other options:

Option B: Central nervous system toxicity. There are no significant central nervous system-related adverse events. In a minority of patients, peripheral neuropathy presenting as shoulder and pelvic muscle weakness is seen.

Option C: Renal dysfunction is not seen with Amiodarone since it is hepatically cleared.

Option D: Ototoxicity is associated with prolonged aminoglycoside use and is not a feature of amiodarone toxicity.

questions.text: A woman diagnosed with DCIS underwent surgery and is now posted for adjuvant radiotherapy with external beam radiotherapy. Which of the following isotopes is commonly used for the same?
questions.solution:
Cobalt-60 isotope is used for external beam radiotherapy (EBRT).

External beam radiotherapy is given as follows:

  • Cobalt machine - Co-60 produces gamma rays. It emits radiation of energy 1.25 MeV.
  • LINAC (linear accelator) - X-ray beams are generated to provide ionising radiation.

The energy spectrum used in radiotehrapy is classified as follows:

  • Orthovoltage - 200-500kV x-rays are produced. It is used to treat skin conditions. 
  • Megavoltage - 1-25 MV x-rays are produced. These are used in modern radiotherapy.

questions.text: Examination of a young man reveals a firm enlargement of the epididymis with normal-feeling testes and beading of the vas deferens. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Anti-tubercular chemotherapy if a primary focus is found, with epididymectomy
Confirmation of genital TB with PCR

questions.solution:
In the clinical scenario above, the presence of a firm enlargement of the epididymis with normal-feeling testes and beading of the vas deferens is specific to genital tuberculosis (TB). The next best step is confirmation with polymerase chain reaction (PCR). 

Secondary tuberculous epididymitis may resolve when the primary focus is treated; hence, a course of anti-tubercular therapy must be completed even if there is no evidence of disease elsewhere.

questions.text: A patient with thyrotoxicosis is being prepared for surgery. Which of the following statements regarding the pre-operative preparation of this patient is wrong?

choices.text: Iodine may be given pre-operatively with Carbimazole
Beta blockers administered pre-operatively must be continued post operatively
Nadolol is given in a once daily regimen pre-operatively
The last dose of Carbimazole must be given 24 hours before surgery

questions.solution:
The last dose of carbimazole may be given the evening before surgery. Beta-blockers, however, if used preoperatively must be given on the morning of surgery as well, and be continued for 1-week post-op. 

Traditional preparation of a thyrotoxic patient aims to make the patient biochemically euthyroid. There are 2 methods of preparation that can be used. 

  • Carbimazole 30-40 mg per day is the drug of choice. When euthyroid (after 8-12 weeks), the dose may be reduced or a block and replace regimen may be used. In the latter case, the patient is supplemented with 0.1-0.15 mg of Thyroxine. 
  • An alternative method is to abolish the clinical manifestations using beta-blockade, which acts on the target organs and not the gland itself. The appropriate doses are Propranolol 40 mg TDS or a longer-acting nadolol 160 mg once daily. It is important to continue treatment upto 7 days post-operatively as beta-blockers do not interfere with the synthesis of hormones and hormone levels may remain high for some days post Thyroidectomy. 

Iodine may be given with Carbimazole or a beta-blocker 10 days before the operation. Iodine produces transient remission if given alone and reduces vascularity, increasing the margin of safety. However, its use is not universal as there are more effective regimens. If Beta-blockers are mistakenly omitted on the morning of surgery, Iodides serve as an extra measure of safety. 

Related Pearl: Thyroid storm / Thyrotoxic crisis:

It is an emergency caused by an acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism. 

Precipitating factors:

  • Abrupt cessation of antithyroid medications
  • Infection
  • When a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy.
  • Thyroid or non-thyroid surgery
  • Trauma in patients with untreated thyrotoxicosis
  • Amiodarone administration or exposure to iodinated contrast agents
  • Following RAI therapy.

Clinical features:

  • Fever
  • Central nervous system agitation or depression
  • Cardiovascular and GI dysfunction, including hepatic failure

Treatment of thyroid storm:

Treatment modality Effect
IV Fluids, ice packs Rehydration and external cooling
Propranolol

Block adrenergic effects

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion

Propylthiouracil
(DOC)

 Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Corticosteroids

Inhibits the release of thyroid hormone from the gland

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Lugol’s iodine/ sodium ipodate Inhibits the release of thyroid hormone from the gland
Digoxin Controls the associated atrial fibrillation
Diuretics and administration of oxygen

To manage the cardiac failure.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient presents with episodic headaches, sweating, and palpitations. Her blood pressure was recorded as 167/110 mmHg and lab investigations revealed elevated plasma metanephrines. An adrenal mass was seen on an abdominal CT scan and a biopsy confirms the diagnosis. Which clinical feature would you not expect to see in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with a patient having the given symptoms with elevated plasma metanephrines, and an adrenal mass is suggestive of a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma. Polyuria (not oliguria) is an expected clinical finding.

Pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine-secreting tumor derived from the chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla. 

Clinical features of pheochromocytoma are due to the autonomic effects of excess epinephrine and norepinephrine. 

  • Weight loss (option A) is due to the increase in catecholamines which increase basal metabolism.
  • Pallor (option B) is due to alpha 1-mediated vasoconstriction. 
  • Abdominal pain (option C) with nausea and vomiting is commonly seen.

Diagnosis of pheochromocytoma requires biochemical testing followed by imaging.

  • Urinary and plasma levels of catecholamines and metanephrines 
  • MRI is the investigation of choice for localizing the tumor 
  • MIBG Scintigraphy and PET Scans like Ga- DOTATE, DOPA- or FDG- PET can be used for extra-adrenal tumors and metastases

Treatment of pheochromocytoma:

Surgical resection of the tumor is the definitive treatment. Preoperatively, an alpha-receptor blocker (phenoxybenzamine) is given to control the effects produced by excess catecholamines. Beta-blockers are used to control tachycardia after adequate alpha blockade is achieved. This is to prevent unrestricted alpha-mediated vasoconstriction. Following surgery, lifelong yearly follow-ups should be done.

Related Pearl: Clinical features of Pheochromocytoma (By frequency of occurrence)

  • Clinical triad:
    • Headaches – M/C symptom
    • Profuse sweating
    • Palpitations and tachycardia
  • Hypertension, sustained or paroxysmal – M/C Sign
  • Anxiety and panic attacks
  • Weight loss
  • Polyuria and polydipsia
  • Constipation
  • Orthostatic hypotension
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy
  • Erythrocytosis
  • Elevated blood sugar
  • Hypercalcemia

questions.text: A 28-year-old man with a history of recurrent headaches comes to the OPD with an acute episode of headache lasting for less than 30 minutes with redness and watering in one eye. Which of the following is not used in the treatment of an acute episode in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient is most likely suffering from cluster headaches. Verapamil is not used for the treatment of acute episodes, but as the first-line preventive treatment for cluster headaches.

Cluster headache is a periodic headache characterized by daily attacks of short-duration unilateral headache lasting 8-10 weeks a year. It presents as severe, unilateral retro-orbital pain with autonomic features, such as unilateral lacrimation, nasal congestion, and conjunctival injection. The pain, though severe, is characteristically brief (15-180 minutes). Patients are usually perfectly well in between episodes.

The most suitable treatment is pharmacologic prevention of future bouts of headaches. An acute episode can be treated with 

  • Sumatriptan 6 mg subcutaneous injection
  • 100% O2 at 10 -12 L/min for 15 - 20 mins
  • Sumatriptan (20 mg) and zolmitriptan (5 mg) nasal spray.
  • Noninvasive vagus nerve stimulation (nVNS) is also approved by the FDA for the treatment of acute episodes of cluster headaches.

The drugs used in the prophylaxis of cluster headaches are:

  • Verapamil - drug of choice
  • Prednisone
  • Lithium
  • Topiramate
  • Gabapentin
  • Melatonin
  • Greater occipital nerve injection with lidocaine and glucocorticoids

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy is rushed to the ER after having choked on a bone while eating. He is responsive but unable to speak. What is to be done next?
questions.solution:
In a choking child (more than 1 year old) or an adult, the first step to be done is to perform Heimlich maneuver which involves delivering abdominal thrusts.

The rescuer should stand or kneel behind the patient and wrap his arms around the patient’s waist. A fist is made with one hand and using the other hand, the fist is driven into the patient’s abdomen with a rapid, forceful upward thrust so as to dislodge the foreign body. This is continued until the foreign body is expelled or if the patient becomes unresponsive.

If the patient becomes unresponsive, immediately start CPR.

The Heimlich maneuver is performed as follows:

  1. Stand behind the person and slightly to one side.
  2. Place your arms around the person's waist.
  3. Make a fist with one hand and place the thumb side against the person's upper abdomen, above the navel and below the ribcage.
  4. Grasp your fist with your other hand and give quick, inward and upward thrusts to the abdomen, using enough force to dislodge the object.
  5. Repeat thrusts until the object is expelled or the person becomes unconscious.

In a choking infant who is responsive, 5 back slaps between the shoulder blades and 5 downward thrusts on the chest are given in order to dislodge the foreign body.

If the patient becomes unresponsive, immediately start CPR.

Other options:

A) Bag and mask ventilation involves providing breaths of air using a bag and mask to a person who is not breathing adequately. While it may be necessary if the person becomes unconscious, it is not the immediate next step for a conscious individual who is unable to speak due to choking.

B) Endoscopic removal involves using a flexible tube with a camera to visualize the airway and remove the obstructing object. This may be considered if the initial Heimlich maneuver is unsuccessful in dislodging the object.

C) Deliver 5 backslaps and 5 chest compressions: This technique, known as back blows and chest thrusts, is recommended for infants under one year of age in cases of choking. In this scenario with an 18-year-old boy, the Heimlich maneuver is the more appropriate action to attempt to clear the airway obstruction.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presents to the OPD with complaints of fever, intermittent abdominal pain, and dysuria. He gives a history of swimming in the freshwater lake 10 days back. Urine microscopy shows the following. Which of the following is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture along with the history of swimming and the image showing ovoid egg, which is non-operculated, with a brownish yellow transparent shell, carrying a terminal spine at one pole are suggestive of infection with Schistosoma hematobium.

Species differentiation of Schistosoma can be done based on the location of the spine as follows:

  • Terminal spine: Schistosoma hematobium
  • Lateral spine: Schistosoma mansoni
  • Rudimentary lateral spine: Schistosoma japonicum

 

Schistosoma mansoni (Option B):

Schistosoma japonicum (Option C):
